Problem:
Imagine a function \( z(t) \) governed by the partial differential equation \( \frac{\partial z}{\partial t} + P(D)z = 0 \), where \( P(D) \) is a linear differential operator. We study the effect of the Fourier transformation \( \mathcal{F}(z(t)) \), which transforms \( z(t) \) into the frequency domain.

If an intervention in the form of an additional operator \( Q(D) \) affecting \( z(t) \) is applied at \( t = t_1 \), will the final frequency response \( \mathcal{F}(z(T)) \) at \( T > t_1 \) be solely determined by the initial \( P(D) \) and not the intervention?
Explanation: The intervention with \( Q(D) \) introduces an additional influence on the evolution of \( z(t) \), affecting how \( z(t) \) transitions from \( t_1 \) to \( T \). This results in a modification of the frequency spectrum at \( T \), making \( \mathcal{F}(z(T)) \) dependent on both \( P(D) \) and \( Q(D) \).
